message: Is an attribute just a smaller part of an element? And can multiple elements be in one element? And what is the difference between a tag and an attribute because they both seem like smaller parts of an element.

recent_replies.message: Every HTML element is defined by a beginning < and a closing >.  Attributes are like additional properties of an element that can be set to certain values.  For example, the <img> element would not do much without the src="" attribute.  Most HTML elements such as <div> may contain any number of children elements and may also have multiple attributes with values.

message: Does it matter if opening and closing tags are on new lines, alone on a particular line of code, or indented to a certain degree? If so, in which cases is it important to separate and distinguish tags, and when does it not impact the code's function?

recent_replies.message: All of the white space and line breaks in your HTML file do not impact the code's function.  In fact, it can all be jammed together when "minified" and it works just fine.  The formatting is just a convenience to make your code easier to read.

message: What's the difference between Strict, Transitional and Fragment?

recent_replies.message: This is pointing back to the varieties of XHTML that were possible back in the old days.  Now we all just use HTML5 so those types are usually not relevant - unless you are doing legacy work on some system for some strange reason.

message: When originally learning HTML, it was taught to end self-closing tags with a slash, i.e. <img src="abc.jpg" alt="abc" />. I noticed that the lessons don't add the slash in the self closing tags. Which is the proper method?

recent_replies.message: You no longer need the closing slash /> but if you do include it, the browser will just ignore it so just don't use it.

message: When declaring a doctype, what's the purpose of the exclamation point at the beginning? The lesson mentioned it was important, but why?

recent_replies.message: This is a holdover from the past when there were many different types or versions of HTML that you could write.  So, you would declare the !DOCTYPE at the top of the document to make it clear which version you were using.  It is only in the last few years that people have all settled on HTML5 being the primary version we all use.

message: I have never used radio buttons or checkboxes until this weeks lesson in codecamp. Why does each button or box need its own <label> tag?

recent_replies.message: Not at all obvious, but it has to do with some elements may not contain any other elements.  These are also known as "void" elements.  For example, a <div> may contain any number of child elements.  An <img> element may not contain any children.
Maybe this is obvious to everyone else, but why are some elements self-closing?

message: How do I know when I'll need to provide alternate fonts for if/when they degrade, and similarly, how do I know when a CSS variable will need a fallback? Do I need to provide fallback/alternates for everything, or are there certain values that are supported pretty much universally? How do I avoid needing to provide too many backup fonts/variable values in my code?

recent_replies.message: Most browsers support so many items these days that you rarely need to specify numerous fallbacks.  It is mostly useful when you are trying to use some new, cutting-edge feature that maybe only one major browser has implemented so far.  There are websites such as caniuse.com that provide grids of browser compatibility.

message: With CSS being capable of so many thing, are there times when you would want to use CSS to perform a task previously done by JavaScript?

recent_replies.message: Yes!  And we will actually use CSS in this class in this manner.  Before CSS animations were possible, people would use JavaScript, but now very advanced animations and transitions are possible with CSS.  And even more advanced animation is possible using JavaScript with libraries such as GreenSock.

message: How do you create a fallback value and what is the purpose?

recent_replies.message:
Here is one way to create fallback values: body{ font-family: super-fancy-font, Arial, sans-serif }

In that example, if the browser cannot use the super-fancy-font, it will use Arial.  If it can't use Arial, it will use a default sans-serif font.

Another way to use fallbacks is when defining and using CSS variables like this:

.box{
  --box-color:#4d4e53;
  --box-padding: 0 10px;

  /* 10px is used because --box-margin is not defined. */
  margin: var(--box-margin, 10px);
}

message: When formatting the margins in your style sheet, is there a time when you would use the "Top Bottom Left Right" method over the clockwise method?

recent_replies.message: Yes, we did that in our .container class we've been working on in class.  By setting margin: 0 auto we said we wanted no top or bottom margin and we wanted the left and right margins to be automatically calculated.

message: How does z-index relate to positioning exactly?

recent_replies.message: The z-index can be used to position elements on top of or behind other elements as you look at them.

message: How common is it for the CSS to be in a styling section at the top of the html instead of in separate, linked external style sheets? Will this be something I run into constantly in my career, or just occasionally?

recent_replies.message: It should be very occasional.  What you will see in the future is more style being added directly inline with elements automatically by frontend JavaScript frameworks such as React and VueJS.  But in that case, the framework is doing the heavy lifting.

message: When would it be beneficial to use the style attribute or style tags over an external style sheet?

recent_replies.message: Rarely.  The external file helps you keep things organized and keeps the html from looking cluttered.

message: What are the differences or benefits between using an id tag or a class tag?

recent_replies.message: A class attribute can be used multiple times on many elements within a page.  A id attribute may be used only once per page.  That is really the only difference and which ones you use are a matter of preference.

function updateRecords(id, prop, value) {
if (!value){
delete collection[id][prop];
return collection;
}
if (prop !== "tracks"){
collection[id][prop]= value;
}else{
if(!collection[id].hasOwnProperty("tracks")) collection[id].tracks =[];
collection[id].tracks.push(value);
}
return collection;
}

Yes, 'flex' is the shorthand for the combination of flex-grown, flex-shrink, and flex-basis.  It is the preferred method as in the example below:

.item { flex: none | [ <'flex-grow'> <'flex-shrink'>? || <'flex-basis'> ] }

message: Do you apply flex-direction to individual elements to make them line up in rows and columns? message: Can ID's and classes be used interchangeably?

recent_replies.message: Not sure what you are asking.  You may use any mix of id and class attributes throughout your document, but they are not interchangeable with each other.

message: when using attributes to style our elements, it says we can "select custom groups of elements..", are these groups something we can define, or does it only apply to predefined things like checkboxes, radio buttons etc?

recent_replies.message: An arbitrary "group" of elements could be those elements that are styled all using the same CSS class.  So, you get to define what the group consists of.

message: What is the easiest way to center text, images, and other elements on any screen?

recent_replies.message: Using FlexBox to justify-content and align-items is probably your best bet.

message: What is the big difference between id and class in CSS? Is there one that you would recommend using over the other or is it just whatever your feeling at the time?

recent_replies.message: An id attribute with its specific name may only be used once within your HTML document.  A class attribute's value can be used on many elements within the page.  That is the difference and your use of either id or class is just a personal preference unless you are following a corporate guide or something other agreed upon system.

message: Does CSS code always go in between a <style> </style> marker? are there other markers that it goes in between?

recent_replies.message: CSS rules are only between <style></style> elements when your CSS is embedded within a specific HTML document.  More often, your CSS is in a completely separate file and loaded by the HTML document.

message: In Free Code Camp we used media query to change color based on screen size. Can all attributes of the page be changed in this way? Is this one of the ways web developers build pages that are responsive to mobile users?

recent_replies.message: Yes and Yes!  With tools like FlexBox and CSS Grid, however, we get some built-in responsiveness and don't have to use media queries nearly as much: https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2018/02/media-queries-responsive-design-2018/

message: When are variables used the most often in CSS? When should you start using them as your code gets bigger?

recent_replies.message: Yes, once you have a CSS pre-processor configured and your project has become somewhat complex, then using variables in your CSS will make sense.

message: Is it standard in the industry to have your CSS and HTML in the same doc, or to have an HTML doc linked to a stylesheet?

recent_replies.message: Usually, CSS and HTML are in separate documents, but some JS frameworks such as VueJS will have you combine HTML, CSS, and JavaScript all in one "single file component".  It's pretty cool: https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/single-file-components.html

message: Does it matter the order you put CSS in?

recent_replies.message: Yes, it does but it is a little more complex once things like inheritance and specificity come into play: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/Introduction_to_CSS/Cascade_and_inheritance

recent_replies.message:
I think the goal is to write minimal/reusable code while paying attention to the way the cascade works and still making the styles behave the way you want. 

Also, I think a generally accepted principle is to style elements from the top down, focusing on elements that will remain the same throughout the site at the top, while creating overrides for specific features at the bottom. So basically you want to go from general to specific as you go deeper into the css. The elements will inherit from their parent element and the bottom of the css or more specific selector will override previously written code. 

For example if every font-family is the same throughout the document you would only need to write it once in the body at the top of the css, then it will be inherited throughout the document. But if each paragraph is a different font-family, you would need to style each paragraph with it's own font-family attribute to override the font-family inherited from the body. 

Hopefully that is on the right track, but that is my understanding of it. There is some great info in these documents.

https://www.w3schools.com/css/css_specificity.asp

https://www.w3.org/Style/LieBos2e/enter/Overview.en.html

message: Is it hard to transfer from one coding language to the another?

recent_replies.message: It's like learning more and more real languages like Spanish, Chinese, etc. The more you learn the easier it is to understand because they use similar properties, just with different syntax. Some languages require every detail (strongly typed language) and some just need some basic inputs and are easier to learn.

It depends on many variables.  Some languages are in a family of "C-based" languages that are all somewhat similar because of their ancestry with the C programming language from decades ago.  A language like C# is very similar to Java because it came shortly after Java was in use and copied many Java features.  If you are really interested in programming languages themselves, you might want to explore classes over in the Computer Science department.  They tend to dig down deeper into languages while we tend to focus on the use and application of the language in a specific area like web development.

recent_replies.message:
This is my understanding of a property vs a key. If you were to create an array of objects of people, the properties of each person would be things like 

  • Hair Color
  • Age
  • Eye Color

A key would be something which helps your program understand which object you are talking about. Something that would be different for every object such as their

  • Social Security Number
  • For cars it would be their VIN number or licence plate

message:
I'm not sure how to post screenshots but in the video "Looping Through a list of numbers" he talks about the following code:

 

<span> v-for = "n in 10"</span>

 

I just want to clarify because I was confused when he was explaining that vue recognizes the number 10 and loop through the range of numbers until you reach 10? I just thought that whatever was in "" was just for display

recent_replies.message: Just like in regular HTML, attribute values are always specified within quotes.  The directive being used dictates how the values inside the quotes are interpreted.  The v-for directive is expecting any values that match the "item in items" pattern so that is why "n in 10" works.  BTW, so would something like "foo in bar" as long as bar is an Array or Object.

recent_replies.message: I can't think of any modern language that approaches the complexity of C++, so no JavaScript as used in the Vue framework will never be that complex.  But there is complexity to JavaScript because it is not object-oriented in the same way as those other languages you mention.  It has prototype inheritance and is a functional language, so it is different.  TypeScript aims to make JavaScript much more useful as something similar to a classic object-oriented language.

Why do arrow functions not work in a Vue instance?

recent_replies.message: From the Vue documentation: Don’t use arrow functions on an options property or callback, such as created: () => console.log(this.a) or vm.$watch('a', newValue => this.myMethod()). Since an arrow function doesn’t have a this, this will be treated as any other variable and lexically looked up through parent scopes until found, often resulting in errors such as Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property of undefinedor Uncaught TypeError: this.myMethod is not a function.

recent_replies.message: You are running Node just as if you were running web server hardware - which is pretty cool and powerful.  That is why the file just shows up in the same folder when it has been written to disk.  If your server was deployed on something like Heroku or Digital Ocean the same thing would happen.  Your file would be written to the server's disk in some folder relative to the location of your Node javascript files.

message: What is the data transfered in from a browser in the format? Why do I need a parser in order to read it and why would node remove the parser from its core modules?

recent_replies.message:
Great question.  The data comes from the client in different formats depending on if it is form data, url-encoded, raw, etc.  It also comes from the client to the server as a stream of little info "packets" that need to be collected until the full amount of data is transferred. This can be kind of complex to handle, so a specific package "body-parser" was written to handle it. 

In the early days of Express, the body-parser package was included as part of the Express framework.  Later on, the team decided all external packages that were essentially middleware should be left out of Express to keep the framework light and lean - developers would just add body-parser on their own if they needed.  Recently, it appears the Express developer team determined practically everybody needs body-parser functionality, so body-parser was added back to the core Express framework.
